review_title: You can do this job...if you want to.
pros:
Okay. I am a reasonable person. I do not hate this job. There are a few things that I think work.

1) Teamwork. Walmart just went through a restructuring. Department managers are a thing of the past. Instead, you have team leads like myself. I oversee 5 departments. The good thing about this is that it helps to break down the walls that divided the departments before. You no longer have department managers that are territorial over their own areas and people. There are only associates within each department. Associates are much more willing to bring variety to their days by assisting in a new way.
2) Technology makes the job super easy. I never really need training on anything. Every device I pick up is as easy as a self-checkout. Nothing I've ever done was "hard."
3) Room for advancement. Walmart will take you as far as you are willing to go. Even now, I am being asked about the next level up. You just have to want it. 
4) The people. The people of Walmart have their own stereotype...but I like them. The customer service interactions are a refreshing break for me at times. I get along with my coworkers as well. I feel like we are soldiers in a war at times...and that brings out a sense of brotherhood.
5) Fast days. You work hard and go home tired.
cons:
1) No victories. The volume of a Walmart Supercenter creates a neverending wave of stock. We have what's known as the dreaded "2-truck night." It's when the warehouse is backed up and sends an extra trailer to your store. These were supposed to end at Christmas, yet here I am on January 29th telling you we had three 2-truck nights this week. It's like trying to mop up the ocean. 
2) Callouts. So, remember what I said about associates being willing to add variety to their days? The best way they have discovered to do this is to stay at home. Imagine, if you will, being the team lead overseeing 3 service areas (paint mixer, fabric cutter, and gun sales) in addition to your other departments. Now, imagine a Saturday that you are working and your ENTIRE TEAM calls in from every department you oversee. You better learn to clone yourself.
3) Morale. The reason they are calling out is because everyone hates their jobs. It is exhausting, thankless work. If you are an upbeat, positive person, you will soon learn how to keep that to yourself.
4) Customer complaints. Go ahead, admit it....you have said that Walmart is greedy because they won't hire any cashiers. You may have angrily told that to a Walmart stockboy while you were 15th in line at checkout. Now go back and read my cons. There were 6 cashiers scheduled...none of them showed up. You told off that stockboy because his coworkers laid out.
5) Micromanagement. There are multiple coaches (formerly assistant managers) in a Walmart Supercenter. If you are a hard worker that comes to work, every single one of them needs you. You are asked to do things that have nothing to do with your area by people you do not directly report to. You have to learn to say "no" to your superiors...which is a weird thing.
Advice to Management
More personnel dollars, not less.
The changes made need revisiting. I can see the improvements. 
A successful leader needs to see their accomplishments at times. If a Team Lead is succeeding in their area, have them help another area for one day to catch them up. Please do not take the Team Lead out of their own area for days until it crumbles, and then put them back to fix it. They will be resentful.

Of course, much of my experience is due to having great leaders and being part of outstanding teams - in a company of scale, there are bound to be some really, REALLY bad ones. I have definitely worked with a few in my time, however they normally end up facing karma at some point. 

I entered the company with 0 credentials, 0 experience, and 0 knowledge of the industry and was promoted at a very young age. My time has been rife with challenges but I cannot believe the amount of trust that was placed into me and the amount of time that was spent with me to ensure my success. 

Most leaders at Walmart never pictured themselves working with the company for so long, but we all eventually find something that keeps us drawn in and motivated. For me - it will always be the people. 

Walmart has a strong culture and a solid set of core values which guide our decision making. It's something that you can really feel that you're playing a role in, something that you can actually place some stock in. 

I can honestly say that I could never see myself working anywhere else.
